verses.text: Therefore, be imitators of God as beloved children.
verses.comment: Paul calls believers to imitate God, emphasizing both holiness and love. Imitation suggests a call to transformation by grace, preparing believers to reflect God's character.

verses.text: And walk in love, just as Christ loved us and gave himself up for us—a fragrant offering and sacrifice to God.
verses.comment: Christ's self-giving is described in sacrificial language, recalling Old Testament offerings. This verse teaches that our lives are intended to be a sacrifice pleasing to God, echoing both literal and spiritual dimensions of Christian life.

verses.text: But sexual immorality and all impurity or covetousness must not even be named among you, as is fitting for saints.
verses.comment: Saints are called to radical moral purity, a theme that echoes throughout scripture. The high standard here points to the transformative work of grace shaping Christian behavior.

verses.text: Let there be no filthiness, nor foolish talk, nor crude joking, which are out of place, but instead let there be thanksgiving.
verses.comment: Speech is as significant as actions; gratitude is held up as the proper attitude, contrasting corrupt language with a heart turned toward God.

verses.text: For you can be sure of this: everyone who is sexually immoral or impure, or who is covetous—that is, an idolater—has no inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.
verses.comment: Here the spiritual consequences of habitual sin are highlighted. Note the linking of covetousness and idolatry, showing how ultimate loyalty belongs to God alone.

verses.text: Let no one deceive you with empty words, for because of these things the wrath of God comes upon the sons of disobedience.
verses.comment: Paul warns against minimizing sin. Divine judgment is real—a teaching consistent throughout Scripture. This reinforces the call to genuine repentance and faith.

verses.text: Therefore do not become partners with them.
verses.comment: A clear separation from sinful practices is commanded. True fellowship is based in shared fidelity to Christ.

verses.text: For at one time you were darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk as children of light—
verses.comment: Believers undergo a real transformation from darkness to light through union with Christ, fulfilling the prophecy of the people dwelling in darkness seeing a great light (Isa. 9:2).

verses.text: for the fruit of light is found in all that is good and right and true.
verses.comment: Goodness, righteousness, and truth mark the believer's life, echoing the fruits of the Spirit and sanctification as an ongoing work.

verses.text: And try to discern what is pleasing to the Lord.
verses.comment: This instruction requires a process of spiritual discernment and growth, inviting believers into deeper relationship and obedience.

verses.text: Take no part in the unfruitful works of darkness, but instead expose them.
verses.comment: The Church is called not just to avoid evil but to actively confront and reveal it, promoting accountability among believers.

verses.text: For it is shameful even to speak of the things done by them in secret.
verses.comment: Paul’s seriousness about sin is clear—some things are so evil that they should not even be discussed.

verses.text: But when anything is exposed by the light, it becomes visible;
verses.comment: Light here represents truth—evil cannot hide when confronted by the holiness of God.

verses.text: for anything that becomes visible is light. Therefore it says: Awake, O sleeper, and rise from the dead, and Christ will shine on you.
verses.comment: A probable early hymn or liturgical saying rooted in Old Testament imagery of awakening and resurrection—hinting at the communal worship context of early believers.

verses.text: Look carefully then how you walk, not as unwise but as wise,
verses.comment: Christian living demands careful discernment—a mark of spiritual maturity and wisdom.

verses.text: making the most of the time, because the days are evil.
verses.comment: Believers are called to intentional stewardship of time and opportunities; this has both communal and individual application in the life of the Church.

verses.text: Therefore do not be foolish, but understand what the will of the Lord is.
verses.comment: The Christian life is one of active discernment and submission to God's will—a process aided by the community.

verses.text: And do not get drunk with wine, for that is recklessness, but be filled with the Spirit.
verses.comment: A contrast is drawn between worldly excess and spiritual fullness. Paul alludes to the outpouring of the Spirit, which frequently occurred in corporate gatherings.

verses.text: Address one another with psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, singing and making melody to the Lord with your heart,
verses.comment: Communal worship is emphasized here. Paul's instructions suggest an ordered, liturgical form of worship, continuing the tradition of psalms and spiritual songs from the Old Covenant.

verses.text: giving thanks always and for everything to God the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.comment: Universal thanksgiving is a core spiritual practice, deepening the believer’s relationship with God the Father through Jesus Christ.

verses.text: submitting to one another out of reverence for Christ.
verses.comment: Mutual submission forms the foundation of Christian community, modeled on Christ’s humility.

verses.text: Wives, submit to your own husbands as to the Lord.
verses.comment: Paul speaks to ordering relationship; see comments on 5:25 for mutuality and sacrificial love.

verses.text: For the husband is the head of the wife, just as Christ is head of the church, his body, and is himself its Savior.
verses.comment: The headship imagery emphasizes Christ’s leadership over the spiritual community. The marriage covenant models Christ’s relationship with the Church, rooted in unity and sacrificial love.

verses.text: Now as the church submits to Christ, so also wives should submit in everything to their husbands.
verses.comment: Paul explores the analogy between marriage and Christ’s bond with His people. The Church’s submission is ultimately a loving response to Christ’s self-giving.

verses.text: Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave himself up for her,
verses.comment: Christ’s sacrificial love for the Church is the ultimate model. Marital love is elevated beyond human affection to a sanctifying, self-giving union.

verses.text: that he might sanctify her, having cleansed her by the washing of water with the word,
verses.comment: Paul uses sacramental language here—'washing of water' is traditionally linked to baptism. The spiritual reality is closely connected to an outward, communal act of incorporation into Christ’s body.

verses.text: so that he might present the church to himself in splendor, without spot or wrinkle or any such thing, but holy and blameless.
verses.comment: This verse looks forward to the future glorification of the Church. The imagery parallels Old Testament wedding language applied to God’s people and hints at the eschatological fulfillment.

verses.text: In the same way, husbands ought to love their wives as their own bodies. He who loves his wife loves himself.
verses.comment: Marriage is portrayed as a mysterious unity, echoing Genesis. The self-giving love is both physical and spiritual.

verses.text: For no one ever hated his own flesh, but nourishes and cherishes it, just as Christ does the church,
verses.comment: Paul continues to affirm Christ’s deep care for the Church, reflected in marital love.

verses.text: because we are members of his body.
verses.comment: The notion of the Church as the body of Christ is central, emphasizing a mystical communion among fellow believers.

verses.text: For this reason a man shall leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife, and the two shall become one flesh.
verses.comment: Paul quotes Genesis, showing the deep biblical roots of marriage as a covenant and spiritual mystery.

verses.text: This mystery is profound, and I am saying that it refers to Christ and the church.
verses.comment: Paul reveals the typology—marriage is a sign pointing to the union between Christ and His people. The term 'mystery' (Greek: musterion) often refers to hidden realities made known in Christ; here, it alludes to both sacramental and spiritual realities.

verses.text: Nevertheless, let each one of you love his wife as himself, and let the wife see that she respects her husband.
verses.comment: The summary command captures the core of the previous verses—love and respect are pillars of marriage, reflecting a Christ-centered relationship and community.
